conclusion: The problem involves determining the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in a rotating rectangular coil in a uniform magnetic field.

The formula for the EMF in a rotating coil is given as \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \), where \( n \) is the number of turns, \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, \( A \) is the area of the coil, \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, and \( t \) is the time.
The area \( A \) of the rectangular coil is calculated using the formula \( A = l_{AB} \cdot l_{BC} \).
Substituting the given values \( l_{AB} = 0.2 \mathrm{m} \) and \( l_{BC} = 0.5 \mathrm{m} \), the area \( A \) is calculated as \( 0.2 \mathrm{m} \times 0.5 \mathrm{m} = 0.1 \mathrm{m}^2 \).
The given values are: magnetic induction intensity \( B = 0.1 \mathrm{T} \), number of turns \( n = 100 \), and angular velocity \( \omega = 100\pi \mathrm{rad/s} \).
The maximum value of the induced EMF occurs when the angle \( \omega t = \frac{\pi}{2} \), and the formula for maximum EMF is \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = n B A \omega \).

Substituting the values \( n = 100 \), \( B = 0.1 \mathrm{T} \), \( A = 0.1 \mathrm{m}^2 \), and \( \omega = 100\pi \mathrm{rad/s} \), the maximum EMF is calculated as \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = 100 \times 0.1 \times 0.1 \times 100\pi = 10\pi \mathrm{V} \).
The magnitude of the induced electromotive force in the coil is \( \boxed{10\pi \mathrm{V}} \).
